konektaSocial.title: Konekta Social
konektaSocial.description: Konekta Social is a modern social media platform built as a fully responsive frontend experience. It focuses on clean UI, fast interactions, and a smooth multilingual user journey.
konektaSocial.overview: Konekta Social is a full‑stack project I built to deepen my understanding of modern frontend engineering while also challenging myself to design and implement a complete backend API. Since no free API offered all the features I needed in one place, I decided to build both sides of the application myself.The project uses a modern, in‑demand tech stack across both frontend and backend. I implemented a full authentication system (email confirmation, password reset, magic links, secure login/logout), although the UI flows UI flows that require email functionality are not active in production because email APIs require a live domain and SMTP is blocked on free hosting tiers.Despite those limitations, the entire system is fully implemented in code and demonstrates real‑world architecture, protected routes, optimistic UI updates, and multilingual support (Arabic + English).
features: Email confirmation, password reset, and magic link flows (UI ready, backend implemented)
Optimistic UI updates for fast interactions
Axios-based API layer with typed responses

architecture.label: Frontend
architecture.value: Next.js App Router with server components, client components where needed, React Query for data fetching and caching, optimistic updates for fast UI, and a modular UI system built with shadcn/ui and TailwindCSS. Axios is used as the main HTTP client with a typed API layer and unified error handling.

architecture.label: Backend
architecture.value: Fastify REST API with a clean modular route structure, Prisma ORM for database access, Zod for schema validation, and JWT-based authentication. Routes are protected using authorization middleware. All backend errors follow a normalized shape to simplify frontend error handling.

architecture.label: Database
architecture.value: PostgreSQL schema designed with Prisma, including users, posts, comments, likes, and other.

challenges: Handling HTTP-only cookies differently in development vs production
Designing a complete authentication system without paid email services
Ensuring consistent error shapes between backend and frontend
Managing optimistic UI updates in a scalable way
Ensuring localization works across routes and components
Managing dark/light theme persistence
Deploying backend + database on Railway free tier with strict limitations
Understanding differences between Vercel, Railway, and Render environments
solutions: Implemented full auth logic with secure HTTP-only cookies and environment-based cookie configuration
Created a normalized backend error format to simplify Axios error handling
Used React Query mutation lifecycle for optimistic updates
Created a reusable i18n dictionary system for AR/EN
Used next-themes for theme persistence
Added fallback UI and warnings for Railway downtime
Learned how Vercel, Railway, and Render handle environment variables, cold starts, and request lifecycles
learnedAspects: How HTTP-only cookies behave differently in dev vs prod (localhost vs HTTPS)
How to normalize backend error shapes for predictable frontend handling
How to structure a scalable Axios API layer
How to debug deployment issues across Vercel, Railway, and Render
How to design backend routes that match real business requirements
How to build a project that feels like a real production system, not a demo
limitations: Email flows cannot run in production because SMTP is blocked on Railway free tier
Backend may sleep or become unavailable due to Railway free tier policies
Some auth UI screens are implemented but disabled in production

konektaBackend.title: Konekta Backend
konektaBackend.description: A scalable backend built with Fastify, TypeScript, Prisma, and PostgreSQL, designed for high‑performance APIs and real‑time features. It includes robust authentication, validation, and modular architecture for future growth.
konektaBackend.overview:
Konekta Backend is the server-side foundation of the Konekta Social platform. I built it using a hands-on, iterative approach—experimenting, breaking things, fixing them, and learning backend engineering concepts through real practice. Throughout the process, I used AI as a learning partner to understand backend patterns, improve my prompting skills, and explore how production-grade APIs are designed.
This project taught me how backend and frontend engineers collaborate through schemas, contracts, and predictable error structures. I learned how to design Prisma schemas, validate data with Zod, structure Fastify routes, and build a clean API that is easy for frontend developers to consume. The experience gave me a strong understanding of how backend logic works, why certain patterns exist, and how to design scalable, maintainable APIs.
I also gained practical experience with deployment environments such as Railway, Render, and Vercel, learning how dev and prod differ in terms of cookies, CORS, headers, cold starts, and request lifecycles. These lessons helped me build a backend that behaves more like a real business-grade system rather than a simple demo.
features: Email confirmation, password reset, and magic link logic (backend implemented)
Typed API responses for frontend integration

architecture.label: Api Design
architecture.value: Modular Fastify route structure with controllers, services, and validation layers. Each endpoint follows a predictable pattern: validate → authorize → execute → respond. Errors follow a normalized shape to simplify frontend handling.

architecture.label: Database
architecture.value: Prisma schema includes users, posts, comments, likes, tokens, and sessions. Relations are designed to support scalable social interactions and efficient querying.

architecture.label: Auth
architecture.value: JWT-based authentication with refresh tokens, secure cookie handling, and environment-based cookie configuration for dev vs prod.

challenges: Understanding how backend routing, validation, and controllers work together
Learning Prisma schema design and relational modeling
Handling HTTP-only cookies differently in dev vs prod
Normalizing error shapes for predictable frontend consumption
Debugging CORS, headers, and cookie issues across Railway, Render, and Vercel
Designing APIs that feel natural for frontend developers
solutions: Used Fastify's plugin system to structure routes cleanly
Designed Prisma schemas through iterative modeling and testing
Implemented environment-based cookie configuration for dev/prod
Created a unified error response format for Axios
Tested deployments across Railway, Render, and Vercel to understand differences
Documented API behavior using Postman for easier frontend integration
learnedAspects: How backend architecture is engineered in real-world systems
How to design Prisma schemas and relational models
How to validate requests using Zod
How to structure Fastify routes and plugins
How HTTP-only cookies behave differently in dev vs prod
How to normalize backend error shapes for frontend clarity
How Railway, Render, and Vercel differ in deployment behavior
How to build APIs that feel intuitive for frontend developers
How to debug CORS, cookies, and headers across environments
How to think like both a frontend and backend engineer

Backend may sleep or become unavailable due to free tier limits
Some advanced auth flows are implemented but not active in production

Add WebSocket support for real-time updates

theDeal.title: TheDeal
theDeal.description: A freelance project built in collaboration with a senior developer. I contributed to the Home page, Projects page, and Podcast page, focusing on clean UI, accessibility, and responsive design. The platform enables users to post job offers, apply for jobs, list projects for sale or scaling, and create role profiles to get hired.
theDeal.overview:
TheDeal was a major opportunity for me to work on a real-world, business-oriented project under the guidance of a senior frontend developer who also acted as a mentor. This experience exposed me to professional development workflows, production standards, and the expectations of high-quality frontend engineering.

The project is fully server-side rendered, which allowed me to discover the true power of Next.js and TypeScript in a real production environment. I contributed three of the main seven pages—Home, Projects, and Podcasts—along with two additional subpages inside the Projects section. Working on these pages helped me understand how to build scalable layouts, reusable UI patterns, and maintainable code structures.

One of the most valuable parts of this project was learning SEO fundamentals. I worked with structured data schemas, metadata optimization, and SEO testing after deployment. I also delivered a fully localized UI, ensuring both Arabic and English versions were polished and consistent.

TheDeal also gave me hands-on experience integrating with a real API built by an experienced backend engineer. I implemented carousels, animated UI components, forms, and dynamic content, all while maintaining accessibility and performance. This project significantly boosted my confidence and made me even more eager to take on larger, more complex challenges.

Three main pages built: Home, Projects, Podcasts

reactTodo.title: Simple React Todo App
reactTodo.description: A simple React practice project focused on building a clean and functional todo application. It includes basic CRUD operations, state management, and a straightforward UI to reinforce core React concepts.
reactTodo.overview:
This project marks the very beginning of my React journey. It was the first real application I built while learning the fundamentals of components, state management, props, and rendering. I chose to keep this project in my portfolio because it reminds me of where I started and how far I've come.

The React Todo App represents the early stages of my growth—experimenting with React, understanding how UI updates work, and learning how to structure small applications. It also helped me get comfortable with Vite, Material UI, and the basics of modern frontend tooling. Keeping this project visible is my way of appreciating the journey, staying humble, and staying motivated to keep improving every day.

hairDayWebsite.title: HairDay Salon
hairDayWebsite.description: HairDay Salon is a simple landing page built using only HTML and CSS as a practice project. The goal was to focus on clean structure, semantic markup, and responsive styling without relying on frameworks.
hairDayWebsite.overview:
HairDay is one of the very first projects I built using only HTML and CSS. Just like my React Todo App, this project represents an important milestone in my learning journey. It reminds me of the early days when everything was new, challenging, and exciting. I keep this project in my portfolio not because of its complexity, but because of what it symbolizes—growth, persistence, and the willingness to start from zero.

Working on HairDay taught me the fundamentals of layout, styling, responsiveness, and structuring a clean HTML document. It also helped me appreciate the importance of design, spacing, and visual hierarchy long before I learned modern frameworks. I am grateful for this project because it marks the beginning of a journey that has taken me through React, Next.js, TypeScript, backend development, and full-stack engineering. It reminds me to stay humble, stay thankful, and keep moving forward.
